text: I think splitting the banks up is the
only thing that really makes sense right
now the wake of the crisis has created
bigger more powerful institutions than
we had going in so this idea of too big
to fail has become actually created um
and embedded as well by the government
last year when the crisis was happening
it was the Federal Reserve was in the
position to for example deny mergers to
deny Banks becoming even bigger than
they were when they were flirting with
failure and instead what the FED did was
prop them up by by guaranteeing um a lot
of the potential losses that could come
from new mergers so for example Bank of
America merged with maril Lynch to
become the biggest most complex
institution in the country um as well as
one that holds a tremendous amount of
consumer deposits uh well Fargo and
movia also merged to become a much
larger institution with a lot of credit
problems um of its own JP Morgan Chase
was given with a lot of government
backing the be Sterns company an
investment bank which has a lot of risk
attached to it as well as Washington
Mutual so you have the top three banks
in the country even bigger and more
powerful and owning more of consumer
deposits and assets then even before the
crisis and that's the completely wrong
thing to the only way you can really
regulate
effectively and back risk if it gets out
of control and and help it from spilling
over into the general economy is to make
things more manageable and smaller and
regulatable to begin with and that would
entail splitting up the banks into
consumer banks that deal with deposits
and loans and checking and savings and
basic funds and investment banks that
can trade and speculate and do whatever
they want with with more regulation so
it doesn't spill into the rest of the
economy
but not with the right to have
government backing when they
fail
